Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================

Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: as one component of the interconnected global ocean, it is connected in the north to the arctic ocean, to the pacific ocean in the southwest, the indian ocean in the southeast, and the southern ocean in the south (other definitions describe the atlantic as extending southward to antarctica).

Training sentence: sargasso sea

gameplay
association football is played in accordance with a set of rules known as the laws of the game.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the game is played using a spherical ball of 68â70 cm (27â28 in) circumference, known as the football (or soccer ball).

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: two teams of eleven players each compete to get the ball into the other team's goal (between the posts and under the bar), thereby scoring a goal.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the team that has scored more goals at the end of the game is the winner; if both teams have scored an equal number of goals then the game is a draw.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: each team is led by a captain who has only one official responsibility as mandated by the laws of the game: to represent his or her team in the coin toss prior to kick-off or penalty kicks.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the primary law is that players other than goalkeepers may not deliberately handle the ball with their hands or arms during play, though they must use both their hands during a throw-in restart.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: although players usually use their feet to move the ball around they may use any part of their body (notably, "heading" with the forehead) other than their hands or arms.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: within normal play, all players are free to play the ball in any direction and move throughout the pitch, though the ball cannot be received in an offside position.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: during gameplay, players attempt to create goal-scoring opportunities through individual control of the ball, such as by dribbling, passing the ball to a teammate, and by taking shots at the goal, which is guarded by the opposing goalkeeper.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: opposing players may try to regain control of the ball by intercepting a pass or through tackling the opponent in possession of the ball; however, physical contact between opponents is restricted.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: football is generally a free-flowing game, with play stopping only when the ball has left the field of play or when play is stopped by the referee for an infringement of the rules.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: after a stoppage, play recommences with a specified restart.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: at a professional level, most matches produce only a few goals.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: for example, the 2005â06 season of the english premier league produced an average of 2.48 goals per match.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the laws of the game do not specify any player positions other than goalkeeper, but a number of specialised roles have evolved.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: broadly, these include three main categories: strikers, or forwards, whose main task is to score goals; defenders, who specialise in preventing their opponents from scoring; and midfielders, who dispossess the opposition and keep possession of the ball to pass it to the forwards on their team.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: players in these positions are referred to as outfield players, to distinguish them from the goalkeeper.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: these positions are further subdivided according to the area of the field in which the player spends most time.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: for example, there are central defenders, and left and right midfielders.

Truth: EN
Hyp: NL
Incorrect
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the ten outfield players may be arranged in any combination.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the number of players in each position determines the style of the team's play; more forwards and fewer defenders creates a more aggressive and offensive-minded game, while the reverse creates a slower, more defensive style of play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: while players typically spend most of the game in a specific position, there are few restrictions on player movement, and players can switch positions at any time.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the layout of a team's players is known as a formation.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: defining the team's formation and tactics is usually the prerogative of the team's manager.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: laws
there are 17 laws in the official laws of the game, each containing a collection of stipulation and guidelines.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the same laws are designed to apply to all levels of football, although certain modifications for groups such as juniors, seniors, women and people with physical disabilities are permitted.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the laws are often framed in broad terms, which allow flexibility in their application depending on the nature of the game.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the laws of the game are published by fifa, but are maintained by the international football association board (ifab).

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in addition to the seventeen laws, numerous ifab decisions and other directives contribute to the regulation of football.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: players, equipment, and officials
each team consists of a maximum of eleven players (excluding substitutes), one of whom must be the goalkeeper.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: competition rules may state a minimum number of players required to constitute a team, which is usually seven.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: goalkeepers are the only players allowed to play the ball with their hands or arms, provided they do so within the penalty area in front of their own goal.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: though there are a variety of positions in which the outfield (non-goalkeeper) players are strategically placed by a coach, these positions are not defined or required by the laws.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the basic equipment or kit players are required to wear includes a shirt, shorts, socks, footwear and adequate shin guards.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: an athletic supporter and protective cup is highly recommended for male players by medical experts and professionals.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: headgear is not a required piece of basic equipment, but players today may choose to wear it to protect themselves from head injury.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: players are forbidden to wear or use anything that is dangerous to themselves or another player, such as jewellery or watches.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the goalkeeper must wear clothing that is easily distinguishable from that worn by the other players and the match officials.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a number of players may be replaced by substitutes during the course of the game.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the maximum number of substitutions permitted in most competitive international and domestic league games is three in ninety minutes with each team being allowed one more if the game should go into extra-time, though the permitted number may vary in other competitions or in friendly matches.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: common reasons for a substitution include injury, tiredness, ineffectiveness, a tactical switch, or timewasting at the end of a finely poised game.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in standard adult matches, a player who has been substituted may not take further part in a match.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: ifab recommends "that a match should not continue if there are fewer than seven players in either team."

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: any decision regarding points awarded for abandoned games is left to the individual football associations.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a game is officiated by a referee, who has "full authority to enforce the laws of the game in connection with the match to which he has been appointed" (law 5), and whose decisions are final.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the referee is assisted by two assistant referees.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in many high-level games there is also a fourth official who assists the referee and may replace another official should the need arise.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: goal line technology is used to measure if the whole ball has crossed the goal-line thereby determining if a goal has or hasn't been scored, this was brought in to prevent there being controversy.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: video assistant referee (var) has also been increasingly introduced to assist officials through video replay to correct clear and obvious mistakes.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: there are four types of calls that can be reviewed: mistaken identity in awarding a red or yellow card, goals and whether there was a violation during the buildup, direct red card decisions, and penalty decisions.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: ball
the ball is spherical with a circumference of between 68 and 70 centimetres (27 and 28 in), a weight in the range of 410 to 450 grams (14 to 16 oz), and a pressure between 0.6 and 1.1 bars (8.5 and 15.6 pounds per square inch) at sea level.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in the past the ball was made up of leather panels sewn together, with a latex bladder for pressurisation but modern balls at all levels of the game are now synthetic.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: pitch
as the laws were formulated in england, and were initially administered solely by the four british football associations within ifab, the standard dimensions of a football pitch were originally expressed in imperial units.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the laws now express dimensions with approximate metric equivalents (followed by traditional units in brackets), though use of imperial units remains popular in english-speaking countries with a relatively recent history of metrication (or only partial metrication), such as britain.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the length of the pitch, or field, for international adult matches is in the range of 100â110 m (110â120 yd) and the width is in the range of 64â75 m (70â80 yd).

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: fields for non-international matches may be 90â120 m (100â130 yd) length and 45â90 m (50â100 yd) in width, provided that the pitch does not become square.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in 2008, the ifab initially approved a fixed size of 105 m (344 ft) long and 68 m (223 ft) wide as a standard pitch dimension for international matches; however, this decision was later put on hold and was never actually implemented.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the longer boundary lines are touchlines, while the shorter boundaries (on which the goals are placed) are goal lines.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a rectangular goal is positioned at the middle of each goal line.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the inner edges of the vertical goal posts must be 24 feet (7.3 m) apart, and the lower edge of the horizontal crossbar supported by the goal posts must be 8 feet (2.4 m) above the ground.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: nets are usually placed behind the goal, but are not required by the laws.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in front of the goal is the penalty area.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: this area is marked by the goal line, two lines starting on the goal line 16.5 m (18 yd) from the goalposts and extending 16.5 m (18 yd) into the pitch perpendicular to the goal line, and a line joining them.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: this area has a number of functions, the most prominent being to mark where the goalkeeper may handle the ball and where a penalty foul by a member of the defending team becomes punishable by a penalty kick.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: other markings define the position of the ball or players at kick-offs, goal kicks, penalty kicks and corner kicks.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: duration and tie-breaking methods
a standard adult football match consists of two halves of 45 minutes each.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped when the ball is out of play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: there is usually a 15-minute half-time break between halves.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the end of the match is known as full-time.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the referee is the official timekeeper for the match, and may make an allowance for time lost through substitutions, injured players requiring attention, or other stoppages.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: this added time is called additional time in fifa documents, but is most commonly referred to as stoppage time or injury time, while loss time can also be used as a synonym.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the duration of stoppage time is at the sole discretion of the referee.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: stoppage time does not fully compensate for the time in which the ball is out of play, and a 90-minute game typically involves about an hour of "effective playing time".

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the referee alone signals the end of the match.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in matches where a fourth official is appointed, towards the end of the half the referee signals how many minutes of stoppage time he intends to add.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the fourth official then informs the players and spectators by holding up a board showing this number.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the signalled stoppage time may be further extended by the referee.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: added time was introduced because of an incident which happened in 1891 during a match between stoke and aston villa.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: trailing 1â0 and with just two minutes remaining, stoke were awarded a penalty.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: villa's goalkeeper kicked the ball out of the ground, and by the time the ball had been recovered, the 90 minutes had elapsed and the game was over.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the same law also states that the duration of either half is extended until the penalty kick to be taken or retaken is completed, thus no game shall end with a penalty to be taken.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in league competitions, games may end in a draw.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in knockout competitions where a winner is required various methods may be employed to break such a deadlock; some competitions may invoke replays.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a game tied at the end of regulation time may go into extra time, which consists of two further 15-minute periods.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: if the score is still tied after extra time, some competitions allow the use of penalty shootouts (known officially in the laws of the game as "kicks from the penalty mark") to determine which team will progress to the next stage of the tournament.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: goals scored during extra time periods count towards the final score of the game, but kicks from the penalty mark are only used to decide the team that progresses to the next part of the tournament (with goals scored in a penalty shootout not making up part of the final score).

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in competitions using two-legged matches, each team competes at home once, with an aggregate score from the two matches deciding which team progresses.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: where aggregates are equal, the away goals rule may be used to determine the winners, in which case the winner is the team that scored the most goals in the leg they played away from home.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: if the result is still equal, extra time and potentially a penalty shootout are required.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the ifab experimented with ways of creating a winner without requiring a penalty shootout, which was often seen as an undesirable way to end a match.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: these involved rules ending a game in extra time early, either when the first goal in extra time was scored (golden goal), or if one team held a lead at the end of the first period of extra time (silver goal).

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: golden goal was used at the world cup in 1998 and 2002. the first world cup game decided by a golden goal was france's victory over paraguay in 1998. germany was the first nation to score a golden goal in a major competition, beating czech republic in the final of euro 1996. silver goal was used in euro 2004. both these experiments have been discontinued by ifab.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: ball in and out of play
under the laws, the two basic states of play during a game are ball in play and ball out of play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: from the beginning of each playing period with a kick-off until the end of the playing period, the ball is in play at all times, except when either the ball leaves the field of play, or play is stopped by the referee.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: when the ball becomes out of play, play is restarted by one of eight restart methods depending on how it went out of play:
kick-off: following a goal by the opposing team, or to begin each period of play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: throw-in: when the ball has crossed the touchline; awarded to the opposing team to that which last touched the ball.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: goal kick: when the ball has wholly crossed the goal line without a goal having been scored and having last been touched by a player of the attacking team; awarded to defending team.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: corner kick: when the ball has wholly crossed the goal line without a goal having been scored and having last been touched by a player of the defending team; awarded to attacking team.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: indirect free kick: awarded to the opposing team following "non-penal" fouls, certain technical infringements, or when play is stopped to caution or dismiss an opponent without a specific foul having occurred.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a goal may not be scored directly (without the ball first touching another player) from an indirect free kick.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: direct free kick: awarded to fouled team following certain listed "penal" fouls.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a goal may be scored directly from a direct free kick.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: penalty kick: awarded to the fouled team following a foul usually punishable by a direct free kick but that has occurred within their opponent's penalty area.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: dropped-ball: occurs when the referee has stopped play for any other reason, such as a serious injury to a player, interference by an external party, or a ball becoming defective.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: misconduct
on-field
a foul occurs when a player commits an offence listed in the laws of the game while the ball is in play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the offences that constitute a foul are listed in law 12. handling the ball deliberately, tripping an opponent, or pushing an opponent, are examples of "penal fouls", punishable by a direct free kick or penalty kick depending on where the offence occurred.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: other fouls are punishable by an indirect free kick.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the referee may punish a player's or substitute's misconduct by a caution (yellow card) or dismissal (red card).

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a second yellow card in the same game leads to a red card, which results in a dismissal.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a player given a yellow card is said to have been "booked", the referee writing the player's name in his official notebook.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: if a player has been dismissed, no substitute can be brought on in their place and the player may not participate in further play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: misconduct may occur at any time, and while the offences that constitute misconduct are listed, the definitions are broad.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: in particular, the offence of "unsporting behaviour" may be used to deal with most events that violate the spirit of the game, even if they are not listed as specific offences.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: a referee can show a yellow or red card to a player, substitute or substituted player.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: non-players such as managers and support staff cannot be shown the yellow or red card, but may be expelled from the technical area if they fail to conduct themselves in a responsible manner.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: rather than stopping play, the referee may allow play to continue if doing so will benefit the team against which an offence has been committed.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: this is known as "playing an advantage".

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the referee may "call back" play and penalise the original offence if the anticipated advantage does not ensue within "a few seconds".

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: even if an offence is not penalised due to advantage being played, the offender may still be sanctioned for misconduct at the next stoppage of play.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the referee's decision in all on-pitch matters is considered final.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================
Training sentence: the score of a match cannot be altered after the game, even if later evidence shows that decisions (including awards/non-awards of goals) were incorrect.

Truth: EN
Hyp: EN
Correct!
==============================
==============================

along with the general administration of the sport, football associations and competition organisers also enforce good conduct in wider aspects of the game, dealing with issues such as comments to the press, clubs' financial management, doping, age fraud and match fixing.

Training sentence: falli e scorrettezze
i falli e le scorrettezze, nel gioco del calcio, sono infrazioni alle regole per le quali l'arbitro deve prendere i dovuti provvedimenti contro il calciatore reo del gesto; nella fattispecie, i falli sono tutte quelle azioni che comportano l'interruzione del gioco e l'assegnazione di un calcio di punizione, diretto od indiretto, o di un calcio di rigore, in favore della squadra avversaria, mentre le scorrettezze sono tutti quegli atti o gesti meritevoli di cartellino (giallo o rosso): possono esistere, quindi, anche delle azioni che siano contemporaneamente sia falli che scorrettezze (come lo spingere un avversario per impedirgli di raggiungere una posizione vantaggiosa, che Ã¨ un fallo perchÃ© passibile di calcio di punizione diretto, ed Ã¨ anche una scorrettezza perchÃ© Ã¨ passibile di ammonizione).

others follow the british historian a. j. p. taylor, who held that the sino-japanese war and war in europe and its colonies occurred simultaneously, and the two wars merged in 1941. this article uses the conventional dating.

the exact date of the war's end is also not universally agreed upon.

pacific (1942â43)

il contesto storico
germania
